MORRIS STARS AS
HAVERFORD WINS
Red And Black Captain
Scores 19 Points
GAME KNOTTED AT HALF
Haverford Overcomes 6-0 Lead
And Wins, 32-8
Having as its chief opponents
rain and Captain Morris, Hopkins
was overcome by a heavier aggregation at Haverford last Saturday
and lost, 32 to 8.
The game began with a rush
which found the Jay team on the
long end of a 6 to 0 score. Keating
received the kick-off from Morris
and carried the ball twenty yards
before he was downed. A series of
line bucks failed to net Hopkins
any material yardage. Turnbull
punted to Litchfield, the Pennsylvanian's safety man. Haverford,
also failing to gain, attempted a
punt. The Hopkins line swamped
the Red and Black backfield to
block the kick. BialoskOrsky fell
on the ball on the enemy eight-yard
line. Turnbull failed to gain on a
line buck. On the next play Turnbull received a short pass from
Guild for the first touchdown after
only five minutes of the contest had
elapsed. The try for point failed.
No Weak Spots

Neither team had had the opportunity during this time to find weak
spots in its opposing line. From the
kick-off, after the touchdown,
Haverford made a determined attempt to knot up the count. In three
successive plays, Litchfield and
Morris advanced the ball 45 yards
to deposit the ball fairly deep in
Black and Blue territory. Hopkins
called for time out with the Red and
Black team's advance to the 17yard line. The Haverford threat
Was short lived, however, Hopkins
gaining the ball on downs. Skirting
right end and left end in that order,
Turnbull and Bledsoe chalked up a
first down. This gain was counteracted by a 15-yard penalty for
holding, forcing Turnbull to punt
to Hagenauer, who advanced the
ball to his 47-yard line. A series
of line bucks and off-tackle plays
netted no yardage. On the next
Play the referee penalized Haverford 15 yards for holding. Morris
punted, the ball rolling behind the
Hopkins goal posts. Turnbull immediately punted, losing no yardage
in exchange. Morris carried the
ball eight yards through tackle, but
his gain was halved When Rosenberg, playing right end for the
Jays, tackled Hagenauer for a fourYard loss. Keating got by Milliken, his opposing man on the line,
to block Morris' attempt to punt.
Ilaverford recovered to successfully punt out of danger to Guild
on the Blue team's 5-yard line. The
first quarter ended with Turnbull's
return punt to Litchfield, leaving
the ball on the latter team's 42-yard
mark, with Hopkins leading by one
touchdown.
Haverford Ties Score

It was in the second quarter that
the rain began. It was also in the
second quarter that Haverford retaliated with six points, the main
liner's heavier weight coming in
to a great advantage. The teams
had waged a nearly equal fight during this portion of the game, with
a slight advantage to the Jays.

SECOND BLUE JAY
OUT NOVEMER 12
The second issue of the
BLUE JAY, originally slated for
issuance on November 5, will
not appear until November 12
according to reports from the
magazine offices. The delay, it
was reported, was made to enable the issue to be sold at the
St. John's game on November
16.
'The organ is expected to
embody a rurnber of outstanding features, 5ncluding a cover
by Bryan Quirk.
The number is to be one pertaining to aviation.

JOE CARTER STARS

GEORGE WASHINGTON
DOWNS J. H. U. FROSH

George Washington Line
Averages 192 Pounds
The George Washington freshman football team dealt a crushing
defeat to the Johns Hopkins freshmen last Saturday, November 2.
The game was played under clear
skies and a hot sun on the Eastern
High School field at Washington,
the home team winning 88 to 0.
Carter Runs 50 Yards

The game started with a flourish
when Carter, of George Washington, ran the kick-off fifty yards.
On the next play Carter, again carrying the ball, took it over for a
touchdown. From then on the Hopkins team was forced to take the
defensive in a vain attempt to keep
the score of the opposing team as
low as possible. At the end of the
first quarter the score stood at
33 to 0.
First Team Goes In

For the second quarter Coach
Mallonee sent in a whole new team.
This new team at least succeeded
in its defensive tactics, for at the
end of the half the score was still
33 to 0. Twice the Blue team recovered fumbles made by the Washington team, but only to be forced
to kick when they found it impossible to gain against the much
heavier line. Stone, McCabe, and
Henderson all tried their hands at
kicking for the Hopkins frosh.
Each of these had at least one kick
blocked when their own line crumbled up under the assault of their
opponents.
In the third quarter, by numerous
end runs, off-tackle plays, and occasionally a pass, the George Washington team succeeded in rolling up
24 more points, making the score
57 to 0.
Defeat No Disgrace

The last quarter proved a duplicate of this and the game ended
88 to 0 in favor of George 'Washington. The victorious team had
used nothing but straight plays
finding it easy to gain through the
Hopkins lighter line. The kicker
of the home team showed unusual
ability on the kick-off. At one time
the ball nearly sailed over the crossbars on the kick-off. As the George
Washington freshman team has on
numerous occasions defeated their
own varsity, the score is really not
as bad as it looks. Their line averaged 192 pounds to the man and
their backfield was composed of

U. S. ENVOY GETS
HOPKINS POST

Entered Service In 1907

"Mr. MacMurray entered the
diplomatic service in 1907 as Secretary of the American Legation
in Bangkok shortly after graduating from Princeton University.
After service in Greece and Montenegro, he returned to the State Department, when he became Chief of
the Far Eastern Division and later
Assistant Secretary of State in
charge of Far Eastern affairs. He
was one of the chief advisers in
Far Eastern problems during the
Washington Arms Conference in
1921, and was appointed Minister
to China in 1925.
Dr. Ames Silent

Dr. Joseph S. Ames expressed
his surprise at the announcement
by saying that "We are not prepared to say anything in connection
with Mr. MacMurray's association
here. I cannot say he will be associated with the faculty in any
way. Any statement coming from
the State Department must stand
for the present."

fri,nrialit, anri

dame fortune have combined to single out twenty men who will guide
their respective classes. Of these twenty, actually perhaps eight or
twelve will share in the actual business of administering the various
duties which have devolved upon them and ultimately the four class
presidents are responsible to his class for its successful management.
Too often campus government has paralleled civil politics with
undesired exactitude. The class president can easily become a mere
pawn in the hands of the faction which put him in office. Be it a
fraternity or non-fraternity group that is responsible for the victory of
a particular candidate, the danger that the electee may allow himself to
be used as a tool for the political aspirations of his backers remains the
same. Though he may owe a certain debt to a limited group, the successful nominee, nevertheless, upon his election, is lifted above party
politics. He becomes the leader of a united class and it should be his
serious duty to fulfill to the best of his ability the obligations which
have become his. We believe with Grover Cleveland, "that public
office is a public trust." The duties imposed upon a class president are
broader than the written requirements of his class constitution. He
must be able to successfully pacify rival factions and to secure harmony
in running the machinery of his class. No wise leader will follow the
precepts of the Spoils System in making the oppointments which
devolve upon him. Every capable faction in the class must be represented; the president has to seek for the ablest representatives of
each group to make up his committees. Friendship will be bound to
play some role in the selection of such committees, but its part should
be minor.
Often a group of officers is elected by a class, the individual members
of which, have little or nothing in common with each other. In such
cases, the president, as the leader, must unify this group and see that
each subordinate officer performs his office as he should.
The vice-presidency and the office of sergeant-at-arms, through continued practice, have become largely honorary. The incumbents of these
two offices must accept with good grace the ornamental position they
occupy.
Particularly must the president of the Senior Class use his executive
qualities without thought of political gain. Second only to the Student
Council president, who is the titular head of the undergraduate body,
the leader of the seniors has a considerable responsibility resting on his
shoulders. He must tackle his job with a view to fairness above all
else. If he does this, he will be above criticism.

COLUMBIA WINS
OVER HARRIERS

Brown Zug-Grain
A sturdy new shoe for young men with a generous measure

Race Run Over Van Cortlandt
Park Course
SCHIEBEL FIRST
First Defeat To Jay Team This
Season
Johns Hopkins cross-country
team suffered its first defeat of the
season Saturday at Van Courtland
Park when Columbia's harriers
scored their first victory at Hopkins' expense, 32 to 23. The meet
was the firt one scheduled between
the two schools and promises to
be the first of a series of pleasant
inter-collegiate track activities.
The race was run over the regulation six-mile course. Herman
Schiebel, the ace of the Hopkins
team romped away to an easy victory, crossing the finish line about
a city block ahead of Joe Hagen,
Columbia's premier runner. The
Black and Blue team was evidently
unfamiliar with the course inasmuch as a few of its members
appeared lost at times.
Columbia Places

The Blue and White team scored
five men of the first seven, thus
insuring a victory. Hagen, Joyce,
Becker, and Cahill, of Columbia,
leaped away to a flying start at the
beginning of the run. At the halfway mark, Schiebel, sporting one
of the most magnificent dashes
ever witnessed at the Van Courtland Park course, burst into the
lead. Kelly, following his teammate's example, dashed into second
place, but so strained himself that
Hagen and Joyce were able to pass
him in the final spurt of flying feet.
McAndris, of Columbia, passed
Emerson, Waters and Packard at
a junction of two paths, when they
seemed unfamiliar with the course.
Schiebel was conceeded to be
the most brilliant runner seen in
New York this fall. At no time
during the race did he seem in
danger of losing his supremacy.

Emerson fought tooth and nail for
the seventh place, which was taken
finally, by one second, by the runner who was more familiar with
the course. McAndris' time was
35.25, while Emerson's was 35.26.
The next two places went to Hopkins. They were taken by Waters
in 35.37, and Packard, a freshman
runner, took tenth place in 35.39.
These were the only places counted
in the scoring as each team took five
out of ten places.
Of the remaining five men only
one was of Hopkins, as Columbia
had nine men running against the
six men from Hopkins. Somers,
of Columbia, who took 35.57 to
make the course, was the only one
of the non-scoring men to beat Miller, who came in two seconds later.
Raith, Strait and Mehans, all of
Columbia, wound up the list of runners with times which ran from
36.04 to 37.10.
Hancock, of Hopkins, was again
kept out of another match by an
injury to his foot which occurred
early this season. It was believed
that it had been sufficiently healed
for him to run, but the doctor
forbade it at the last moment.

While rambling amidst newlypainted floring and miscellaneous
electric wiring one is immediately
struck by the size of the new Physics Building. Consisting of five
floors it is a very appreciable addition to the campus.
With the exception of the mathematics department, which is holding forth on the first floor, the entire building is to be devoted to the
study of Physics.
A large lecture hall and two complete machine shops are also features of the new building. The title
"Student Shop," to be found on
one of the doors does not mean that
a book store or the like is within.
It merely happens that one of the
machine shops has been set aside
to be used by students themselves
when they wish to fabricate a piece
of apparatus instead of having the
machinist make it up.

Large cellars completely walledin with one door only are to be
found in the lower regions of the
Physics Building. They 4-e for
the personal use of"?" to store"?."
Several tunnels were discovered
leading off to various corners of the
campus but as the supply of matches
ran out only one extremely warm
one, leading to the power house,
could be explored. Switch-boards
worthy of any Consolidated Gas
Company power house are stuck
away in various corners.
The most noticeable thing in the
whole building, however, is not the
laboratories, nor tunnels. Just why
this building should be equipped
ith the most brilliant, eerie, triangular red "exit" signs ever seen,
is not known. These meet one at
every corner and serve to show (we
suppose) the wandering freshman
how to get to the open air in the
shortest possible time after a lecture.

MORRIS STARS AS
HAVERFORD WINS
Red And Black Captain
Scores 19 Points
GAME KNOTTED AT HALF
Haverford Overcomes 6-0 Lead
And Wins, 32-8
Having as its chief opponents
rain and Captain Morris, Hopkins
was overcome by a heavier aggregation at Haverford last Saturday
and lost, 32 to 8.
The game began with a rush
which found the Jay team on the
long end of a 6 to 0 score. Keating
received the kick-off from Morris
and carried the ball twenty yards
before he was downed. A series of
line bucks failed to net Hopkins
any material yardage. Turnbull
punted to Litchfield, the Pennsylvanian's safety man. Haverford,
also failing to gain, attempted a
punt. The Hopkins line swamped
the Red and Black backfield to
block the kick. BialoskOrsky fell
on the ball on the enemy eight-yard
line. Turnbull failed to gain on a
line buck. On the next play Turnbull received a short pass from
Guild for the first touchdown after
only five minutes of the contest had
elapsed. The try for point failed.
No Weak Spots

Neither team had had the opportunity during this time to find weak
spots in its opposing line. From the
kick-off, after the touchdown,
Haverford made a determined attempt to knot up the count. In three
successive plays, Litchfield and
Morris advanced the ball 45 yards
to deposit the ball fairly deep in
Black and Blue territory. Hopkins
called for time out with the Red and
Black team's advance to the 17yard line. The Haverford threat
Was short lived, however, Hopkins
gaining the ball on downs. Skirting
right end and left end in that order,
Turnbull and Bledsoe chalked up a
first down. This gain was counteracted by a 15-yard penalty for
holding, forcing Turnbull to punt
to Hagenauer, who advanced the
ball to his 47-yard line. A series
of line bucks and off-tackle plays
netted no yardage. On the next
Play the referee penalized Haverford 15 yards for holding. Morris
punted, the ball rolling behind the
Hopkins goal posts. Turnbull immediately punted, losing no yardage
in exchange. Morris carried the
ball eight yards through tackle, but
his gain was halved When Rosenberg, playing right end for the
Jays, tackled Hagenauer for a fourYard loss. Keating got by Milliken, his opposing man on the line,
to block Morris' attempt to punt.
Ilaverford recovered to successfully punt out of danger to Guild
on the Blue team's 5-yard line. The
first quarter ended with Turnbull's
return punt to Litchfield, leaving
the ball on the latter team's 42-yard
mark, with Hopkins leading by one
touchdown.
Haverford Ties Score

It was in the second quarter that
the rain began. It was also in the
second quarter that Haverford retaliated with six points, the main
liner's heavier weight coming in
to a great advantage. The teams
had waged a nearly equal fight during this portion of the game, with
a slight advantage to the Jays.

JOE CARTER STARS

GEORGE WASHINGTON
DOWNS J. H. U. FROSH

George Washington Line
Averages 192 Pounds
The George Washington freshman football team dealt a crushing
defeat to the Johns Hopkins freshmen last Saturday, November 2.
The game was played under clear
skies and a hot sun on the Eastern
High School field at Washington,
the home team winning 88 to 0.
Carter Runs 50 Yards

The game started with a flourish
when Carter, of George Washington, ran the kick-off fifty yards.
On the next play Carter, again carrying the ball, took it over for a
touchdown. From then on the Hopkins team was forced to take the
defensive in a vain attempt to keep
the score of the opposing team as
low as possible. At the end of the
first quarter the score stood at
33 to 0.
First Team Goes In

For the second quarter Coach
Mallonee sent in a whole new team.
This new team at least succeeded
in its defensive tactics, for at the
end of the half the score was still
33 to 0. Twice the Blue team recovered fumbles made by the Washington team, but only to be forced
to kick when they found it impossible to gain against the much

U. S. ENVOY GETS
HOPKINS POST

Entered Service In 1907

"Mr. MacMurray entered the
diplomatic service in 1907 as Secretary of the American Legation
in Bangkok shortly after graduating from Princeton University.
After service in Greece and Montenegro, he returned to the State Department, when he became Chief of
the Far Eastern Division and later
Assistant Secretary of State in
charge of Far Eastern affairs. He
was one of the chief advisers in
Far Eastern problems during the
Washington Arms Conference in
1921, and was appointed Minister
to China in 1925.
Dr. Ames Silent

Dr. Joseph S. Ames expressed
his surprise at the announcement
by saying that "We are not prepared to say anything in connection
with Mr. MacMurray's association
here. I cannot say he will be associated with the faculty in any
way. Any statement coming from
the State Department must stand
for the present."

fri,nrialit, anri

dame fortune have combined to single out twenty men who will guide
their respective classes. Of these twenty, actually perhaps eight or
twelve will share in the actual business of administering the various
duties which have devolved upon them and ultimately the four class
presidents are responsible to his class for its successful management.
Too often campus government has paralleled civil politics with
undesired exactitude. The class president can easily become a mere
pawn in the hands of the faction which put him in office. Be it a
fraternity or non-fraternity group that is responsible for the victory of
a particular candidate, the danger that the electee may allow himself to
be used as a tool for the political aspirations of his backers remains the
same. Though he may owe a certain debt to a limited group, the successful nominee, nevertheless, upon his election, is lifted above party
politics. He becomes the leader of a united class and it should be his
serious duty to fulfill to the best of his ability the obligations which
have become his. We believe with Grover Cleveland, "that public
office is a public trust." The duties imposed upon a class president are
broader than the written requirements of his class constitution. He
must be able to successfully pacify rival factions and to secure harmony
in running the machinery of his class. No wise leader will follow the
precepts of the Spoils System in making the oppointments which
devolve upon him. Every capable faction in the class must be represented; the president has to seek for the ablest representatives of
each group to make up his committees. Friendship will be bound to
play some role in the selection of such committees, but its part should
be minor.
Often a group of officers is elected by a class, the individual members
of which, have little or nothing in common with each other. In such
cases, the president, as the leader, must unify this group and see that
each subordinate officer performs his office as he should.
The vice-presidency and the office of sergeant-at-arms, through continued practice, have become largely honorary. The incumbents of these
two offices must accept with good grace the ornamental position they
occupy.
Particularly must the president of the Senior Class use his executive
qualities without thought of political gain. Second only to the Student
Council president, who is the titular head of the undergraduate body,
the leader of the seniors has a considerable responsibility resting on his
shoulders. He must tackle his job with a view to fairness above all
else. If he does this, he will be above criticism.

Race Run Over Van Cortlandt
Park Course
SCHIEBEL FIRST
First Defeat To Jay Team This
Season
Johns Hopkins cross-country
team suffered its first defeat of the
season Saturday at Van Courtland
Park when Columbia's harriers
scored their first victory at Hopkins' expense, 32 to 23. The meet
was the firt one scheduled between
the two schools and promises to
be the first of a series of pleasant
inter-collegiate track activities.
The race was run over the regulation six-mile course. Herman
Schiebel, the ace of the Hopkins
team romped away to an easy victory, crossing the finish line about
a city block ahead of Joe Hagen,
Columbia's premier runner. The
Black and Blue team was evidently
unfamiliar with the course inasmuch as a few of its members
appeared lost at times.
Columbia Places

The Blue and White team scored
five men of the first seven, thus
insuring a victory. Hagen, Joyce,
Becker, and Cahill, of Columbia,
leaped away to a flying start at the
beginning of the run. At the halfway mark, Schiebel, sporting one
of the most magnificent dashes
ever witnessed at the Van Courtland Park course, burst into the
lead. Kelly, following his teammate's example, dashed into second
place, but so strained himself that
Hagen and Joyce were able to pass
him in the final spurt of flying feet.
McAndris, of Columbia, passed
Emerson, Waters and Packard at
a junction of two paths, when they
seemed unfamiliar with the course.
Schiebel was conceeded to be
the most brilliant runner seen in
New York this fall. At no time
during the race did he seem in
danger of losing his supremacy.

While rambling amidst newlypainted floring and miscellaneous
electric wiring one is immediately
struck by the size of the new Physics Building. Consisting of five
floors it is a very appreciable addition to the campus.
With the exception of the mathematics department, which is holding forth on the first floor, the entire building is to be devoted to the
study of Physics.
A large lecture hall and two complete machine shops are also features of the new building. The title
"Student Shop," to be found on
one of the doors does not mean that
a book store or the like is within.
It merely happens that one of the
machine shops has been set aside
to be used by students themselves
when they wish to fabricate a piece
of apparatus instead of having the
machinist make it up.

Large cellars completely walledin with one door only are to be
found in the lower regions of the
Physics Building. They 4-e for
the personal use of"?" to store"?."
Several tunnels were discovered
leading off to various corners of the
campus but as the supply of matches
ran out only one extremely warm
one, leading to the power house,
could be explored. Switch-boards
worthy of any Consolidated Gas
Company power house are stuck
away in various corners.
The most noticeable thing in the
whole building, however, is not the
laboratories, nor tunnels. Just why
this building should be equipped
ith the most brilliant, eerie, triangular red "exit" signs ever seen,
is not known. These meet one at
every corner and serve to show (we
suppose) the wandering freshman
how to get to the open air in the
shortest possible time after a lecture.

What Is A Speakeasy'

It turns out that no one knows
what a speakeasy is; that everyone
believes whiskey can be delivered;
and that someone has seen a college boy drink.
The girls retire to another room
to discuss their lurid experiences
privately and the newspaper reporter sneaks out the back way.
Somehow or other you wish you
were either with the girls or with
the newspaper reporter.
The head man asks, when do college boys drink? He asks, where do
college boys drink? He asks, why do
college boys drink? The newspaper
man sneaks back for his hat. You
sneak after the newspaper man,
feeling that the liquor situation is
well in hand.
